misconceptions.name: Misinterpreted problem requirements (implemented a different problem)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented an average acceleration calculator instead of a program that reads 5 integers and prints the sum of the even ones, indicating a misunderstanding of what the assignment is asking for.
misconceptions.student_belief: I believe the task is to read v0, v1, and t as doubles and compute the average acceleration using (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task is to read exactly 5 integers from the user, use a loop to process them, check which ones are even using `n % 2 == 0`, and compute and print the sum of only those even integers.
symptoms: Prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers.
Reads three double values rather than five integers.
No loop over 5 inputs.
No conditional even check or sum of even numbers.
Output message describes average acceleration instead of sum of even numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion with a different textbook/example problem (average acceleration) or not reading the current assignment specification carefully.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement slowly and underline the key requirements: number of inputs (5), input type (integers), required operation (sum only even numbers). Then redesign the program structure around those requirements before writing code.
related_concepts: Mapping problem requirements to program structure
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is dedicated to computing average acceleration with variables v0, v1, and t, with no elements related to summing 5 integers, so the mismatch with the problem statement is clear and consistent.

evidence.note: This code clearly implements an average acceleration calculation, not reading 5 integers and summing the even ones.

misconceptions.name: Mismatched Program Submission
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a program designed to calculate average acceleration based on initial velocity, final velocity, and time, instead of the required program for finding the sum of five input integers (filtering for evens). None of the requirements of Q1 were addressed.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student either copied/submitted code for the wrong assignment or fundamentally misunderstood the requirements of Q1, confusing it with a physics calculation problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The required solution must involve reading exactly five integers, using a loop, employing conditional logic (modulo operator %) to check for evenness, and accumulating the results.
symptoms: Program prompts for 'v0, v1, and t:'
No loop structure present for 5 inputs
No use of the modulo operator (%)
Calculates and prints 'average acceleration'
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to adhere to the problem requirements; submission of code for an incorrect assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the specific rubric and prompt for Q1. Erase the current code and start fresh, focusing only on the steps necessary to read 5 integers and sum the even ones.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code 'AccelerationCalculator' and the internal logic (v1-v0)/t confirms with certainty that the wrong problem was solved.

evidence.note: The entire program is dedicated to calculating acceleration, proving the submission is for the wrong problem.

misconceptions.name: Completely Wrong Problem Solution
misconceptions.description: Student solved a different problem entirely (acceleration calculation) instead of the assigned problem (sum of even numbers). This indicates a fundamental misunderstanding of the problem requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they should calculate acceleration from velocity and time values, rather than read integers and sum the even ones.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading exactly 5 integers from the user and calculating the sum of only those that are even (divisible by 2). The correct logic should check each number with n % 2 == 0 and accumulate only even numbers.
symptoms: Program reads 3 floating-point values instead of 5 integers
Program performs acceleration calculation instead of filtering and summing
Output is completely unrelated to the required 'Sum of even numbers' format
No loop structure to process multiple inputs
No conditional check for even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Student either misread the problem, copied code from a different assignment, or did not carefully verify that their solution matches the problem requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. The program should: (1) read exactly 5 integers, (2) loop through them, (3) check if each is even using n % 2 == 0, (4) sum only the even ones, (5) print the sum in the format 'Sum of even numbers: X'
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence because the submitted code solves a completely different problem (acceleration calculation). There is no overlap in logic, inputs, or outputs with the required solution.

evidence.note: The entire solution calculates acceleration instead of summing even numbers. Reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers, performs physics calculation instead of filtering, and produces wrong output format.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements (acceleration calculator instead of sum of even numbers)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program that computes average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of a program that reads 5 integers and prints the sum of the even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: I need to write a program that reads initial velocity, final velocity, and time, then calculates the average acceleration using (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task is to read exactly five integers from the user, use a loop to process them, check each number for evenness (n % 2 == 0), accumulate the sum of only the even numbers, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of five integers.
Program reads three double values rather than five integers.
No loop is used to handle five separate inputs.
No conditional check for even numbers or accumulator for their sum.
Output describes 'average acceleration' rather than 'sum of even numbers'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely reuse of a previous example (average acceleration) without adapting it to the new problem statement, indicating a difficulty in mapping written requirements to code structure.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the problem and rewrite it in your own words before coding. Identify the required inputs (five integers), the processing steps (loop, even check with n % 2 == 0, summing only evens), and the exact required output message. Then design the program structure around those specific requirements.
related_concepts: Input design based on problem statements
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program consistently implements an average acceleration calculator; there is no evidence of handling five integers, checking evenness, or summing them.

evidence.note: The code clearly reads three doubles v0, v1, t and computes (v1 - v0) / t, printing 'The average acceleration is ...', which does not match the requirement to read 5 integers and sum the even ones.

misconceptions.name: Fundamental Misinterpretation of Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for calculating average acceleration (a physics formula problem), instead of solving the assigned task, which was calculating the sum of 5 even numbers. The code provided does not address any aspect of the required prompt.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe this code satisfies the requirements for summing even numbers, or they submitted code intended for a completely different assignment (e.g., Q2 if this was a multi-part assignment).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The correct assignment requires reading 5 integers, iterating through them, checking for parity using the modulo operator (%), and accumulating a sum only if the number is even.
symptoms: Code reads three double values (v0, v1, t) instead of five integers.
Code performs an unrelated mathematical calculation for acceleration.
Code outputs 'The average acceleration is...' instead of 'Sum of even numbers: '.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding or complete disregard of the assignment prompt specifications (Q1: Sum of Even Numbers).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the specific prompt and start over, focusing on the required steps: input handling, looping 5 times, conditional logic (if number % 2 == 0), and accumulation.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code snippet is entirely dedicated to solving a physics problem (average acceleration = (v1-v0)/t), which directly contradicts the assigned problem (Sum of Even Numbers).

evidence.note: The class name suggests an entirely different purpose.
Reads three double inputs (v0, v1, t) instead of five integer inputs required by the prompt.
Performs an unrelated calculation (acceleration formula) rather than summing even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Problem Misinterpretation - Wrong Algorithm Entirely
misconceptions.description: The student has fundamentally misunderstood the assignment and implemented a solution to a physics acceleration problem instead of a sum-of-even-numbers problem. This suggests a critical failure to read or comprehend the problem requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe this assignment is about calculating acceleration from three physics variables (v0, v1, t).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading 5 integers from the user, filtering for even numbers only, and summing them. Example: inputs [3, 8, 2, 7, 4] should sum the even numbers [8, 2, 4] to get 14.
symptoms: Code reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
No loop structure present
No conditional check for even/odd
Calculates acceleration instead of sum
Output shows acceleration value, not sum of evens
misconceptions.root_cause: Student did not carefully read the assignment specification or submitted code from a different assignment. Fundamental misalignment between the code's purpose and the stated problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem carefully. You need to: (1) Use Scanner to read 5 integers, (2) Use a for/while loop to process all 5, (3) Check if each number is even using (n % 2 == 0), (4) Add even numbers to a sum variable, (5) Print the final sum.
related_concepts: Problem comprehension and careful requirement reading
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The submitted code is an entirely different algorithm (physics acceleration calculation) compared to the required algorithm (sum of even integers). There is no overlap in logic, variable usage, or output format.

evidence.note: Reads 3 doubles with physics variable names instead of 5 integers for the sum-of-evens problem
Calculates physics acceleration formula instead of filtering/summing even numbers
Outputs acceleration instead of sum of even numbers
